instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3476: What is 820-3476? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.C7050: What is C7050? Capacitor between current sense lines on ISL6259 chip for battery current sensing, you should measure around 2.202 ohms across this. Often when the resistance across this capacitor is higher it is because one of the current sense resistors going to the ISL6259 chip has failed. When current sensing resistors between the shunt resistor and the ISL6259 power IC have failed the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being sent to or drawn from the battery, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing/sending power to the battery as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..
definitions.U7090: What is U7090? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V42_G3H.
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .
definitions.SPI_MLB_MOSI: What is SPI_MLB_MOSI? SPI_MLB_MOSI is a line between the SPI ROM BIOS chip and resistors that sit between it and the PCH. This often corrodes on Macbook Airs due to liquid damage and results in missing PM_SLP_S4_L and no bootup..
definitions.SPI_MLB_MISO: What is SPI_MLB_MISO? SPI_MLB_MISO is a line between the SPI ROM BIOS chip and resistors that sit between it and the PCH. This often corrodes on Macbook Airs due to liquid damage and results in missing PM_SLP_S4_L and no bootup..

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Help a beginner
threads.message:
Hey guys, just diving in to board level laptop repairs here, I purchased a dead water damaged Macbook Air and also this Retina 13in to begin my learning quest. Macbook Air was repaired after hours and hours of watching Louis's videos which I'm absolutely stoked about! Thanks Louis! But now this <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board is giving me issues. So I'm here to get some pointers hopefully..

Firstly the laptop would not power, no orange, no green lights. Dead in every aspect. Found some minor corrosion around <CAPACITOR>C7050</CAPACITOR> and <CAPACITOR>C7060</CAPACITOR>. Replaced <CAPACITOR>C7060</CAPACITOR> and cleaned the rest in the ultrasonic. Now I have orange and green lights and the fans spin so I reassembled into laptop.

Although I get the orange light and fans come on I still get no chime and nothing on the screen. After a couple mins the fan starts going extreme.

I then started measuring power rails, everything is present.

Does anyone have any suggestions on where I should start looking now? I feel like I was making progress in my learning here but have hit a pretty big wall and am stumped basically.

Going to study the way the LCD works over lunch and see if that can give me some insight otherwise any pushes in the right direction would be lovely!

Thanks
Rob

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Help a beginner
threads.message: does it work with thunderbolt to vga adapter into a monitor, give you a questionmark folder? does it light a USB mouse?

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Help a beginner
threads.message:
hey mate, thanks for the reply. Confidence has gone from sky high to rock bottom here.. 

To answer your questions, only have thunderbolt to hdmi so can't test that. No there is no question mark folder (LCD doesn't seem to even show a backlight) and when I plug in a USB mouse it lights up for half a second.

I have started from scratch again, testing the one wire circuit and power rails. Now please correct me if I'm wrong or if my thinking is way off track. I think my learning curve is just starting to rise now..

<CHIP>U7090</CHIP> Pin 6 vin should be 3.42v right? It gets it from <DIODE>D7005</DIODE> which has 14.5v on pin 1, pin 2 and pin 3, the 3 resistors <CAPACITOR>C7092</CAPACITOR> <CAPACITOR>C7091</CAPACITOR> <CAPACITOR>C7090</CAPACITOR> all make sure <CHIP>U7090</CHIP> gets the correct 3.42v?

My VIN on PIN 6 of <CHIP>U7090</CHIP> is still the 14.5v measured from <DIODE>D7005</DIODE>. So do I have a part that isn't pulling the voltage down to 3.42v? Is <DIODE>D7005</DIODE> not doing its job?

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Help a beginner
threads.message: also seen one of you videos where you describe it as a possible cpu vcore issue? When there is no chime.. Need to try find that vid next I think.

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Help a beginner
threads.message:
if it turns on from a charger who cares about onewire circuit, we need brain. why check the onewire circuit if it has power from a charger? look at the purpose of that circuit. 

think of this like heart and brain. heart is working, it turns on. now we need brain(light on mouse, chime, etc)

threads.message: Sounds like I need to apply more logic..

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Help a beginner
threads.message:
I'm lost, 5hrs down and counting here.. Determination definitely isn't the issue. Alas I have no idea why the CPU isn't working and I have no idea what to look at next. The vcore power rail exists. Being only my second ever attempt at repairing boards I obviously have a fuck load of learning left to do.

Any more subtle tips to try and help push me in the right direction? Thanks

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Help a beginner
threads.message: I'll continue this tomorrow with a fresh brain and a different approach. Been a 13hr day here, going home to refresh on all Louis's videos again.

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Help a beginner
threads.message:
Ok so the cpu doesn't seem to be getting <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>

Follow it back to <CHIP>U7310</CHIP> and <CHIP>U7320</CHIP>. They both have very low readings from pins 2,1,8,5. Pin 6 is showing <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>.

But those pins go to a transistor so at pin 2 of L7310 and L7320 I should have 1.8v. But I don't. 

Gonna leave it for now. Come back again when my brain comes up with any new knowledge.

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Help a beginner
threads.message: Where was the corrosion? There is no CPU Vcore because the regulator is not told to turn on. Probably corrosion on resistors from SPI ROM, or crap around clock chip.

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Help a beginner
threads.message: Was very minor corrosion around <CAPACITOR>C7050</CAPACITOR> <CAPACITOR>C7060</CAPACITOR> (above battery connector) and I replaced one of them and got the green light back.

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Help a beginner
threads.message: Giving up. Repairing this is beyond me it seems. Gonna eBay the board as is with NFI what's wrong.

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Help a beginner
threads.message: Did you check <RESISTOR>R6110</RESISTOR>/20 and that whole lot in the SPI lines?

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Help a beginner
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R6110</RESISTOR> <RESISTOR>R6120</RESISTOR> test fine. 
I found that I do have:
<SIGNAL>SPI_MLB_CS_L</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>SPI_MLB_CLK</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>SPI_MLB_MISO</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>SPI_MLB_MOSI</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>SPI_CSO_L</SIGNAL>

There were a couple other spi lines I can't remember as well but no problems found. 
Thanks for your time here though!

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Help a beginner
threads.message: dont give up bro dont give up

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Help a beginner
threads.message:
For fuck fucking sake. It's fixed. 
These things don't chime when you turn them on. Have tested on 3 others now. 
My problem was the lcd cable. I changed lcd cable. Still didn't chime. Swore a few more thousand times looked at laptop and low and behold. It's fucking working. Perfectly. 

Thank fuck for persistence.

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Help a beginner
threads.message: Yes they do chime, do a PRAM reset. If the volume was turned down on the last time it was booted there will be no chime.

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Help a beginner
